data.title: Geronimo (1962)
data.meta_description: In 1883, the Apache Indians lead by Geronimo reluctantly surrender to the attacks of American and Mexican troops, in exchange for a territory and food for their warriors. Soon though, Geronimo escapes the camps and declares war against the Americans.
data.text:
I've now seen two films named Geronimo this year, and by the time you add Zero Dark Thirty's "Geronimo" Codeword for when Seal Team Six killed Bin Laden, that had both Hillary Clinton and Barrack Obama creaming themselves, I've had a busy time with the former Apache Chief lately. This one stars Chuck Connors, an actor whose range is about the same as a paper aeroplane, although to be fair I wouldn't have said that to his face. He was 6"5", a former NBA and MLB player, and was born Kevin Joseph Aloysius Connors, and unbelievably he changed his name to Chuck before he became a professional athlete? Having realised that he wouldn't make it as a pro, although he…

In 1883 the Apache Indians are surrendering their land and freedom to the American troops in exchange for food and life on a reserve. When their leader Geronimo arrives and sees the lives they are living he escapes and gathers as many of his people as he can to stand against the Americans. Geronimo is an interesting take on this historical story that actually shows good and bad on both sides of the battle, but ultimately suffers from being a bit dry and dull.

At first its it's easy to root for Geronimo (Chuck Connors in makeup) and his people, but as time goes on his stubbornness to change in any way and his poor treatment of women certainly taint…

A fine historical drama, Geronimo has a terrific lead performance from actor Chuck Connors, who plays the legendary historical Apache Leader with flair. Geronimo is a well directed Western film with a good story, engaging performances and good action. With a good blend of drama and action set in the Old West, you get a film that is engaging from the start, and Connors is quite good here and I’ve seen quite a few films with him, but here, this is easily my favorite performances of his. The recounts the ordeal of Geronimo, and it makes for a compelling, worthwhile film going experience. There are plenty of good things here that makes this a solid Western that is a fine…
